awd_titl_txt: Enhancing Community College STEM Teaching through Faculty Development
awd_abstract_narration:
This project aims to serve the national interest in high quality undergraduate STEM education by improving a faculty professional development model focused on improving STEM teaching.  Specifically, this project will support faculty to create STEM course modules that include issues of civic engagement and equity.  Community colleges provide STEM education to an increasingly diverse audience.  This education needs to provide students with STEM knowledge and skills, as well as equip them with both systems thinking and civic engagement tools.  To achieve these educational goals, the project will help faculty improve their STEM courses by developing course modules that address the science of environmental change within a socially relevant context.  This approach may provide a scalable model for strengthening STEM teaching and learning, while simultaneously broadening participation in STEM and preparing citizens and scientists for 21st century challenges.

This project builds upon and extends Bellevue College’s and North Seattle College’s successful faculty professional development efforts by incorporating two curriculum design frameworks:  Science Education for New Civic Engagement and Responsibility and the Equity Ethic.  The project will develop a new professional development curriculum intended to support STEM faculty as they modify environmental lessons to build students' civic engagement, systems thinking, and equity-minded skills. The project will analyze the effectiveness of this course module approach versus a traditional whole-course approach. The project plans to engage at least 35 STEM faculty and 1,800 STEM students at the two colleges, with the potential to impact many more faculty and students if the model is adopted by other institutions. The design of a transferrable professional development curriculum will benefit from the two-college collaboration, which enables the investigators to pilot, revise, and implement the curriculum in two different community college contexts.  These two contexts will enable large scale implementation and comparative evaluation. The project team will conduct a comprehensive evaluation of the effects of the professional development curriculum on STEM teaching, the impact of the modules on student learning outcomes, and how incorporation of the modules affects students’ systems thinking skills as related to civic engagement and equity.  All materials and results from this project will be broadly disseminated at local, regional, and national scales. The NSF IUSE: EHR Program supports research and development projects to improve the effectiveness of STEM education for all students.  This Level 1 project is situation within the Engaged Student Learning track, through which the program supports the creation, exploration, and implementation of promising practices and tools.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Enhancing Community College STEM Teaching through Faculty Development Project is transforming community college STEM education by integrating real world societal issues and systems thinking into teaching. Using evidence-based frameworks, our project focuses on faculty professional development (PD) and course modules to enhance student learning and engagement. It marks the first comprehensive study of course modules, rather than entire courses, in promoting integration of real-world issues into 100-200 level STEM courses. Research in General Chemistry explores how students develop systems thinking skills and an understanding of STEM’s connections to societal issues, laying a foundation for adapting this approach in other STEM fields like physics and math.

The project also aimed to increase STEM persistence, particularly for underrepresented groups and women, by supporting first- and second-year students at a critical stage of their education. The PD model was designed to be flexible, accessible to part-time faculty, and scalable across campuses, fostering broader participation and systemic change. Faculty refined their teaching practices through iterative evaluation, doubling the number of archived course modules and STEM faculty involved while tripling the number of students impacted. Through partnerships with established networks and national organizations, the project’s innovative approach and findings are being widely shared, creating lasting improvements in STEM education.

Over the three years of the grant, the program transformed STEM education by training community college faculty to integrate issues relevant to society, and systems thinking into their teaching. A total of 46 faculty participated, with 40 actively creating course modules that helped students connect STEM knowledge to real-world issues. These modules guided students in activities ranging from analyzing community texts to taking direct action, such as presenting research to local councils. This approach adapted a 4-year college model to meet the unique needs of community colleges, providing opportunities for faculty and students to engage in meaningful, real world issues focused STEM learning.

The project also examined how these modules impacted students’ systems thinking skills. Case studies on water contamination challenged students to analyze real world systems and assess how changes affected ecological and social outcomes. Initial findings from 226 students revealed progress in understanding the interplay of science and social systems. Faculty used refined rubrics and assessments to evaluate these skills, with further analysis ongoing.

The program’s reach extended beyond participating faculty. Over 5,000 educators engaged in workshops and events, and 27 modules were published on a dedicated website for broad access. Faculty shared results through conference presentations and peer-reviewed publications.

The program also scaled statewide. A $1.5 million investment by Washington’s State Board of Community and Technical Colleges enabled the training of 34 faculty leaders, who in turn trained 170 more faculty, reaching over 4,000 STEM students. Many colleges secured funding to sustain the program, ensuring continued growth and impact.

Students reported increased awareness of societal issue driving climate challenges and felt motivated to become engaged. Surveys revealed that 65% of participants prioritized careers that helped others, reflecting the program’s emphasis on empowering students to connect how STEM can help solve problems in their communities. Focus groups highlighted the relevance of societal issues-focused education, particularly for underrepresented groups, affirming its role in fostering STEM engagement and meaningful learning. The project empowered a new generation of STEM learners to address pressing social and environmental challenges.
